stimulus:
Consent Form

Purpose: The purpose of this study is to understand how people think about the physical and social world.

Procedures: In this study, you will watch videos, read sentences, or see pictures, and answer simple questions about them. This study should take approximately 4 minutes.

Participation: Participation in this study is voluntary. If you decide to join now, you can change your mind later.

Payment: You will be paid $15.00/hour for participating in this study. Given the estimated duration of 4 minutes, your payment will amount to $1.00.

Risks and benefits: There are no risks associated with participating in this study. There are no direct benefits associated with participating in this study.

Use of data by study researchers: The research team led by Shari Liu at JHU will have access to your answers.

Publication of results: The results of the research may be presented at scientific meetings or published in scientific journals. Your individual responses may be published. We will never publish your name, the date that you participated, and any other information that could be used to identify you.

Researcher contact information: This study is run by Dr. Shari Liu at JHU. If you have any questions or concerns about this study, or in the very unlikely event of a research-related injury, please contact sliu199@jhu.edu.

Research rights information: If you have questions about your rights as a research participant or feel that you have not been treated fairly, please call the Homewood Institutional Review Board at Johns Hopkins University at (410) 516-6580. If you have any questions or issues completing the survey, please email Shari Liu at sliu199@jhu.edu.

Do you consent to participate?

response: {"feedback":"In one example in particular where I didn't really have very good options I thought that if I was not able to make the creature feel hunger that perhaps if the creature went for a walk the exercise might work up an appetite and so then the creature would feel hunger. That's an example of where I substituted a physical activity for a mental activity. I was thinking of cause and effect. That's the one example that really stands out in my mind. Overall, it was frustrating at times because the options were not going to necessarily produce the desired effect and so I had to rely on hoping for a sequence, of one ability leading to the desired ability. Thank you for the opportunity to participate; I greatly appreciate it!","age":"65","gender":"Female","other_gender":"","race":"Black/African American","other_race":"","ethnicity":"Non-Hispanic"}
feedback: In one example in particular where I didn't really have very good options I thought that if I was not able to make the creature feel hunger that perhaps if the creature went for a walk the exercise might work up an appetite and so then the creature would feel hunger. That's an example of where I substituted a physical activity for a mental activity. I was thinking of cause and effect. That's the one example that really stands out in my mind. Overall, it was frustrating at times because the options were not going to necessarily produce the desired effect and so I had to rely on hoping for a sequence, of one ability leading to the desired ability. Thank you for the opportunity to participate; I greatly appreciate it!
